title: Friday, 11th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Some week, huh?

BE

Paul's around, but not currently at his desk.

BE

So it's up to me to pick the portrait.

11:02 am
BE

BE

FTSE tick chart, two day view.

BE

Market's basically unchanged from pre Mario.

11:03 am
BE

We've been up, and down, but in essence we're flat.

BE

(Last night, someone told me off for saying "basically" too much on here. Basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically basically.)

BE

(@cheeckychappy: ?)

11:04 am
BE

Should we get the bazooka grey out of the way?

BE

That the bazooka's been pulled out is good news, or bad news, or perhaps just middling news.

BE

Morgan Stanley makes this point over 19 pages, involving seven analysts and strategists.

11:05 am
BE

Going well beyond market expectations, the ECB announced a
comprehensive easing package today. In addition, it is still ready to
do more if needed and still sees downside risks to the outlook.
Going well beyond market expectations, the ECB announced a
comprehensive package of easing measures after today's Governing
Council meeting. The measures announced include interest rate reductions,
additional asset purchases (including corporate debt) and new
attractive funding facilities for banks.

BE

The policy decision was supported by an overwhelming majority of the
Governing Council, and hence has not been unanimous. Note that arch-hawk
Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann will not have had a vote today due to
the regular rotation. But ECB President Mario Draghi stressed during the Q&A
that the rotation system, which has been in place since the beginning of last
year, does not make any material difference in terms of the decision making of
the Governing Council as everyone participates in the discussions.

BE

The far reaching package was triggered by an aggressive downward
revision to the ECB staff projections, which now peg the average inflation
rate at an average 0.1% for this year and at only 1.3% next year. In addition, the
ECB experts revised down their growth forecasts to just 1.4% for 2016, 1.7%
for 2017 and 1.8% for 2018. Note that these new staff projections are not
including today’s measures or include them only to the extent that they were
already priced into the markets a few weeks ago.

11:06 am
BE

Skipping a bit.

BE

In our view, both the extension of the asset purchase programme to corporate
debt and the new TLTRO are designed to create a meaningful easing in
credit conditions.
Banks can tap the TLTRO funding up to 30% of their eligible loan stock as per
end of January 2016. The rate they will be charged depends on the policy rate
at the time the funds are taken out and their new loan generation. It can be as
low as the deposit rate. The new funding lines will be providing security
about funding costs even beyond Draghi’s term at the ECB, which ends
in late 2019.
Banks will also be able to roll their existing TLTRO take-up into the new
facility. The option to tap four-year funding at as little as -40 bp is likely to
bring some relief to those banks in the periphery who are expanding their loan
books and who were suffering from negative interest rates affecting the part of
their loan books that is indexed to money market rates.
With this comprehensive package, the ECB aims to restore price
stability and aid the transmission of its monetary policy to the real
economy. The package is designed to also leverage the synergies
effects between the different measures. We will be judging the
effectiveness of the policy package based on our Financial Conditions
Index, our Credit Impulse Metric and new Loan Growth to the SMEs.

BE

And here's Secker on the equity strategy side.

11:07 am
BE

1) Although the ECB policy response was larger and more aggressive than most anticipated, we do not feel inclined to change our cautious view on European equities at this stage. In absolute terms equity valuations are high (the median stock trades on a N12M PE of 15.8) and the latest initiatives are unlikely to materially change the negative trajectory of the market's EPS. If the EUR fails to weaken in the coming days it may actually increase investor fears that central banks are losing their ability to influence asset markets.

BE

2) Post the recent rally in commodities, financials
are the main 'unloved value' laggard left behind.
As we show in Exhibit 16 just 6pc of European banks
outperformed the market over the last 3M, a record low.
With relative valuations also very low (Exhibit 17 shows
they are close to prior structural troughs in 2000 and
2008), it shouldn't take much in the way of good news
to see the sector rally. Today's ECB initiatives should
support our existing view to be OW banks and UW
Insurance with the prospect of even lower yields on
even more assets hurting reinvestment return prospects
for the latter.

BE

Exhibit 16 is .....

11:08 am
BE

BE

3) Our FX strategy team believe that today's events
bring us closer to a renewed rally in USD. Under this
scenario we'd expect the strong rebound in commodity
sectors – that has occurred precisely in line with USD weakness as shown in Exhibit 18 – to reverse. On that
basis it may also bring into question the prospect of a wider rotation into Value.

PM

Back

11:08 am
PM

Sorry about that

BE

No probs. Exhibits 17 and 18 are ....

BE

11:10 am
BE

And in terms of the bond buying programme, Barclays can grey us.

BE

Important details that are yet to be disclosed:

· Will there be a formal target for the volume of corporate bond purchases? (We expect not)

· Will non-bank non-financials be eligible? (eg, insurance companies)

· Will captive finance units be excluded if they hold a banking license? (We believe they will be excluded)

· Will the ECB be able to participate in primary markets? (We expect it to participate in primary)

· Will there be concentration limits? (We expect this to be the case, but at a high level – eg, 50%)

· How will the country of risk “look through” to the underlying entity – eg, the Luxembourg financing entity of a US issuer? (We expect the ECB to look through to the parent country of risk)

· Will there be country or sector guidance along the line of capital keys? (We expect this not to be the case)

BE

We note that these questions may not be answered until the April meeting of the Governing Council, based on the experience of ABS and covered bond purchases announced in Q2 14.

While the market reaction was sharp, with iTraxx Main as much as 12bp tighter at the intra-day lows, we believe it will take several sessions for the market to validate these levels, first in secondary markets and then again in primary markets. Issuers will need to establish the levels at which they can raise fresh capital in the corporate bond markets, and given the large number of unknowns and the gap until the ECB becomes active in the corporate bond market (in late Q2), this process could be a stressful an volatile one. We expect issuers to test the market next week, ahead of the Easter period.

Based on the ECB’s eligible collateral list, we estimate that there is at least c.€700bn of eligible securities outstanding (par value). Focusing on index-eligible debt, this falls to €580bn (€610bn including non-bank financial issuers), still a sizeable amount but one that is likely to fall further in the context of (likely) concentration limits. Overall we estimate that the ECB could plausibly buy €10-15bn of corporate securities per month under this program if it were willing to be price-insensitive and absorb a high percentage of eligible deals in primary markets (in line with the 50% participation in covered bond primary markets seen over recent months). Long term, we believe operational frictions could push realized volumes towards the lower end of that range (ie, €10bn), though we note that with secondary prices well above par (in aggregate), the par amount of purchases that are required would be somewhat lower than implied by headline figures.

11:11 am
BE

Or if you prefer, here's Morgan Stanley's pie chart.

BE

PM

Urg, not really. Everything's up except for a few things that are down.

11:14 am
BE

(#addedvalue)

BE

We can start with the fallers, if you wish.

PM

11:15 am
BE

Old Mutual's arrived at a breakup plan that wasn't half as interesting as the journey to that breakup plan.

PM

Mangy Old Mut

Old Mutual PLC (OML:LSE): Last: 177.80, down 7.5 (-4.05%), High: 191.50, Low: 175.50, Volume: 13.72m
11:15 am
BE

News that Wealth would be split off was widely expected, of course, having popped up over the weekend.

PM

http://www.investe...1603110700107715R/

BE

And really, it was the only possible conclusion of the strategic review announced in November.

11:16 am
BE

So what we're getting is four stand-alone Old Mutuals by 2018

BE

EM, UK Wealth, Nedbank and OMAM

PM

It's going to take almost three years to do this?

11:17 am
BE

Yep, and the "how" isn't really answered.

PM

Doesnt seem to be answered at all

BE

Nothing whatsoever on how it'll actually split out UK Wealth -- as in, half the value of Old Mut on a sum-of-the-parts basis.

11:18 am
BE

Which is following the reports last week about PE interest.

BE

(@cheeckychappy: as ever in these circumstances, one assumes that if there was anything price sensitive to tell us they'd have to tell us.)

BE

Who can we quote on this? Well, now about Nedbank?

11:19 am
BE

Which seems to be commentating on its own breakup.

BE

Analyst here is Grant Davids.

BE

Old Mutual’s new strategy refocuses the business on emerging markets. Head-office debt reduction forms part of this journey, and developed-market asset disposals are likely to fund this. Dividend cover will rise, while the UK wealth business again increased the estimated cost of platform development.

11:21 am
BE

We expect Old Mutual will ultimately consist of the EM business and a minority stake in Nedbank, with a listing in SA only. Exit from OMW will be by separate UK listing or outright sale, in our view. We understand there are no current offers for OMW. An OMW sale or listing needs to take account of the £250m increase in UK platform development costs, with delivery date extended to 2019. An OMAM exit may be easier, in our view, as the business is listed.

BE

Old Mutual also announced a new capital-management policy. The dividend cover range changes from 2.0-2.25x adjusted operating earnings to 2.5-3.5x at each reporting period. According to management, the higher dividend cover is to allow for costs of the separation process (expected to be materially complete by 2018), investment needed by the business units and to maintain capital strength of the underlying businesses. Old Mutual plc has debt of around £1.4bn, which management aims to materially reduce during the separation period.

BE

The underlying businesses performed well for FY15, particularly EM and OMW. OMW exceeded its £270m earnings target. Old Mutual reported Solvency 2 surplus of £1.6bn and cover ratio of 135%. This is lower relative to UK peers as it excludes £0.8bn surplus from OMEM and Nedbank. We have made no changes to our fair value and earnings forecasts at this stage.

11:22 am
BE

Three pages of disclaimers on that note, incidentally.

PM

This seems a complete muddle actually

BE

Old Mut was always a muddle. Anyone surprised that it'll take a few years to unpick hasn't paid enough attention to the previous several decades.

11:23 am
PM

Mangy Old Mut muddle

BE

Oh, should also note that the divi's lower than expected.

BE

Because we're still in the weird world where financial services companies with wafer thin capital buffers and solvency ratios are expected to pay dividends. I dunno. Whatever.

11:24 am
BE

Here's UBS's very short summary.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Operating earnings were c2% below our expectations, in line with consensus at
c£1,663m. New business volumes in SA came in c8% ahead of our estimate and
consensus at £650m. Dividend per share was behind our and consensus estimates at
8.9p with its FGD surplus in line. Solvency II coverage of 135 was slightly higher than
we expected.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: While overall the result looks in line, we note the increased cost guidance and
further delays in the Old Mutual Wealth business's system migration (£450m vs
previous guidance of c£200m) which is likely to attract investor attention, in our view.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No material change to guidance was given.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Given recent share strength and lack of the emergence of a bid for the UK
operations, we expect investors to react with caution to these results.

BE

And that'll do for that.

11:25 am
undefined
PM

See this stuff from Turkey?

PM

There’s a specter haunting stock traders in Istanbul that some are calling “the dude.”

11:26 am
PM

A mystery investor who first appeared a year and a half ago with $450 million of bets on a single day, almost double the market average, is now executing major transactions with increasing frequency, scaring away competitors who can’t figure out when he or she will strike next, traders and bankers said.
Turgay Ozaner and his partners at Istanbul Portfolio have been scouring the official daily trading recap for months for signs of the shadowy figure’s identity, but it’s a code they’ve yet to crack. Whoever it is seems to have skipped from one local brokerage to the next honing his system and turning the latest, Yatirim Finansman, into the biggest net buyer on the market by far.

PM

Is this for real?

PM

http://www.bloombe...-with-massive-bets

11:26 am
PM

At least one European bank’s clients have stopped taking short-term positions in Turkish stocks after concluding the investor is using an algorithmic system in which complex formulas decide trades, while others are avoiding the market until they have more information, a person familiar with the matter said.

PM

I'm not saying this is made up but...

PM

Back in the day people used to make up mystery market operators all the time.

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 179.00, up 16 (+9.82%), High: 183.25, Low: 168.00, Volume: 867.01k
11:40 am
PM

Who is behind this?

BE

Well ... It's basically for sale, as we know.

BE

And Singer reckons a bidder might just appear.

11:40 am
BE

We visited Imagination in Kings Langley yesterday. In our last note we outlined a scenario where the group reduced R&D costs by a further £8.5m, which would result in our DCF derived TP increasing to 191p. While we do not make any changes to our current forecasts, we view this scenario as increasingly likely and upgrade our TP accordingly. We continue to expect the current trading environment to be tough, but given the strength of the group’s unique IP, believe any material share price weakness could bring potential bidders for the company out of the woodwork. We believe Imagination is a highly attractive asset and would expect a bid to be in excess of our new TP. We upgrade to Buy and increase our TP to 191p (from 151p).

BE

Which is indeed an argument.

BE

And I guess there are parallels to draw with CSR, which also had unique IP that wasn't quite as good as other people's unique IP, but still drew an offer.

11:42 am
PM

(Golly G -- not on my screen, it's not )

BE

Singer enjoyed their visit though.

BE

Post the visit we remain convinced that the
group’s core platforms are well aligned with
the emerging trends in the industry.
PowerVR is likely to benefit from ever
growing demands at the high end, as well
as a competitive mid-range solution. We
expect MIPS to continue to establish itself as
a credible alternative to ARM and we see
Ensigma’s communications capability as
becoming increasingly important as the
number of connected devices increases.

11:42 am
BE

Offsetting the strong medium term drivers
are weaker conditions for current trading.
As previously highlighted, royalty revenues
are being impacted by slowing Apple sales
and the weak macro environment is
making the timing of licence deals hard to
predict. The group needs to close c.£6.4m
of licences between Feb and April to meet
our current forecasts. The pipeline supports
this number but we do not discount the
possibility of a shortfall.

BE

We believe that the long payback period
on investments in this type of business and
the comparatively short time horizons of
investors will continue to cause friction. That
said we believe the group’s IP has
significant strategic value and that the new
executive team is committed to maximising
shareholder value. Ultimately we believe
that on a medium term view the shares are
highly attractive. Buy

BE

(Via: nope, don't think so. Not in the disclaimer list.)

BP SAYS CANCELS LONG-TERM PARTNERSHIP WITH TATE BRITAIN AS IT FACES EXTREMELY CHALLENGING BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT

11:44 am

BP had a partnership with Tate Britain?

Actually, the Indie had the stor last night

http://www.indepen...2017-a6923471.html

11:45 am
PM

Supported it for 30 years

BE

And the Guardian was chewing this particular bone in January: http://www.theguar...-sponsorship-money

BE

On Monday, the debate over the rights and wrongs of BP sponsorship was thrust back in to the spotlight when Tate was forced to release 17 years of historic figures, which showed that BP gave sums of £150,000 to £330,000 between 1990 and 2006, an average of £245,000 a year, and a total of £3.8m.

11:46 am
BE

The benefits for Tate are large. BP sponsors the collection displays, the bread and butter of its operations, allowing it to regularly change what is on view. It is one of the only galleries to have this kind of deal, as big business is normally attracted to the sexier blockbuster exhibitions where there is a better chance of publicity. BP, say supporters, deserve credit.

BE

Campaigners say the BP money is an “embarrassingly” tiny proportion of Tate’s overall operational income – just 0.5% during the overall period of 1990-2006. The campaign group Platform has also extrapolated that, while BP sponsorship in 1990-91 represented 17.6% of Tate’s total self-generated income, by 2006-07 it was just 0.74%.

BE

I'm finding myself unscandalised by all this.

11:47 am
BE

BP gives the Tate a bit of money, but not that much, and puts its logos on some things. And now it won't.

BE

It's not like they're painting petrol stations onto the Turners? Are they?

BE

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz42auEJptG

A $101m cyber heist has left central bank officials from Bangladesh to New York arguing over what may be one of the largest and most audacious bank raids in history.
Hackers allegedly breached the Bangladesh central bank’s security system and then masqueraded as Bangladeshi officials to submit a series of requests for the New York Federal Reserve to transfer large tranches of money from its account there.

PM

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz42auPKWw9

Bangladesh banking officials told Reuters that the cyber criminals were ultimately stopped when they made a spelling mistake in one of their transfer instructions. The hackers misspelled the name of a Sri Lankan non-governmental organisation, writing “foundation” as “fandation”. That prompted a routing bank to query the transaction and led to the crime being stopped, Reuters reported.
